title: About Me Site
body:
This is a site that was built early on in my formal web development learning process.

Disclaimer: This project does not necessarily reflect my current abilities. It's a nice reminder of how far I've come in my learning process. I'd love to revisit this at a later date to improve the navigation and game interface.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, JavaScript.

title: Donut Shop
body:
This app is a forecaster for a fictional set of Donut Shops that was designed to be used by the shop employees.

I began by building out the tables for each shop's data using HTML and then gradually added more functionality through JavaScript to dynamically fill the data in the tables. This taught me how to better utilize JavaScript Objects to store data within an application and to build out things with scalability in mind.

My favorite feature of this is the interactivity where the user can select a specific shop to show as well as update the data within the tables.

Some enhancement ideas include but aren't limited to: adding an input field where the user can add a new shop table to the app as well as adding persistence to store the changes made to the numbers that the user has entered.

title: Vote Tracker
body:
This app allows users to vote on their preferred item, stores the vote, and then displays the totals in a graph using the canvasJS library.

An enhancement that I'd like to add would be drag and drop, so the user can reorder the chart items.

This was one of the first times that I've worked with a third party developed JavaScript library and it was a ton of fun.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and the canvasJS library.

title: Discover Portland
body:
Unsure what to do this weekend? Are you currently in Portland, OR? Well you're in luck, because this site can help suggest fun activities in the area.

This was one of my first collaboration projects using git. My team was looking to solve the problem of not being able to decide what to do when you have visitors from out of town.

Due to time constraints, we decided it was best to use radio buttons for the activity picker, however we're looking to rewrite the logic to allow for checkboxes instead. This way, you wouldn't have to rely on the 'reset' button to clear out the current selections.

This app also keeps the currently selected radio boxes in the browser's local storage, just in case the site visitor navigates away from the page to view an external resource and wants to come back to the activities page just as they left it. My main contribution to this was writing the underlying JS logic for the radio buttons on the 'activities' page.

title: Rock Paper Scissors
body:
Originally, I built this game to teach myself flow control via if/else statements in JavaScript, but this actually turned into a much larger project.

I went down the rabbit hole of Google's developer documentation and realized that building a Chrome extension was much easier than I originally thought.

Some add ons that I'd like to explore in the future include: adding persistence, so the choices/scores stay in place if you close out of the popup. It would also be neat to refactor this code to be a bit more compact, possibly with a library such as jQuery.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, JSON.
